repnme.cdata!:
Integrated water resources management in a
            water-scarce region : Tunisia's First Water Sector
            Investment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The first objective of the Water Sector
            Investment Project was to promote effective integrated water
            resource management by establishing and implementing a sound
            institutional framework and sector reform measures for
            demand management (revised tariff policy, new institutional
            arrangements); ensuring the capacity of the government,
            WUAs, and private operators to efficiently manage resources;
            and facilitating real time management of surface and
            groundwater. The second objective was to promote
            conservation of water resources and environmental
            protection. In 2000, the Government of Tunisia's goals
            in the sector were to further reduce vulnerability to
            irregular rainfall and droughts, manage demand in order to
            avoid water shortages in the future, and expand access to
            drinking water for the rural population. An action plan
            produced by the Ministry of Agriculture and Hydraulic
            Resources identified five priority areas: management of
            water demand; integrated water resource management;
            completion of the water resource mobilization program;
            development of non-conventional water resources; and
            preservation and protection of water resources. As the first
            of two consecutive projects, the Water Sector Investment
            Project I (implemented from 2001 to 2007) was designed to
            assist with the first phase of this action plan.

repnme.cdata!: Tunisia - Water Sector Investment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Water Sector Investment
            Loan Project for Tunisia were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the outputs of this project are
            significant and exceed expectations. Yet it is not possible
            to show that those investments generated their intended
            benefits because the objectives and results indicators do
            not reflect the activities that absorbed the greatest share
            of the funding. And the objectives that the project did have
            are too imprecisely defined to be useful to stimulate better
            integration, knowledge sharing and institutional change and
            as such represent a missed opportunity. This imprecision
            allowed those managing the project to focus on the component
            outputs rather than the overall strategic objective. Greater
            attention should have been given to social aspects in the
            design and implementation of the project which would
            probably have helped to improve the performance of certain
            investments. For example, the demand for individual
            household water supply connections should have better
            estimated. Also, the complexity of socio-economic issues
            should have been better addressed in the context of water
            resource management issues. Reducing consumption of
            groundwater is essentially an exercise in changing
            incentives to farmers and thus the groundwater management
            components would have benefited from the advice of a rural
            sociologist. Similarly, technical assistance supporting the
            associations of farmers managing irrigation schemes and of
            households managing rural water supply would have benefited
            from support from qualified sociologist.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Water Sector Investment Project for
            Tunisia aims to promote effective integrated water resource
            management; and to promote water resources conservation and
            environmental protection. There are five project components.
            The first helps create small, tubewell-based, irrigation
            perimeters; modernizes and rehabilitates existing
            perimeters; drains installations on irrigated perimeters;
            electrifies water sources and tubewells for potable water
            and/or irrigation in order to reduce energy and maintenance
            costs; creates water points in the southern arid zone; and
            works towards flood water management. The second component
            helps drill exploratory wells and piezometers, protects and
            rehabilitates existing ones; develops infrastructure for
            artificial groundwater recharge from available surface
            water; and pilots participatory management approaches. The
            third component monitors the quality and quantity of water
            resources; and protects the water resource base and soils.
            The fourth component provides potable water to rural
            dwellers. The fifth component helps develop new skills
            mainly oriented toward planning and demand management in the
            water sector while strengthening the agricultural
            ministry's (MOA) capacity regulation control and
            strategic planning. This component also finances a
            capacity-building effort for water user associations,
            nongovernmental organizations, and private entrepreneurs in
            the water sector.

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Water Sector Investment Loan
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment identifies
            major adverse impacts as a result of the Water Sector
            Investment Loan Project in Tunisia, but does not explicitly
            identify social issues. It does however, cover institutional
            arrangements, budget estimates, and monitoring, and
            evaluation of actions. Mitigation will ensure a sustained
            use of soil resources in irrigation, through studies on
            systematic rapid assessment of soil salinization, and soil
            degradation, to be carried out by the Directorate of Soils,
            and, to improve water resources, studies conducted by the
            Ministry of Environment, will focus on water pollution
            analysis, with support from consulting firms. Institutional,
            and legal measures include staff training in environmental,
            and social assessment requirements, regarding irrigation
            development, groundwater management, and rural water supply,
            as well as a review of contracting environmental clauses.
            Specific measures will: design, and protect terraces to
            minimize surface erosion; avoid water logging, and improve
            drainage to periodically flush spoils; prod cultivation of
            salinity tolerance crops; ensure quality of waste water used
            in irrigation; protect soil surfaces with mulch; establish
            adequate drainage channels, and re-vegetate eroded surfaces;
            include precautionary measures to collect, and recycle
            lubricants to prevent accidental spillage; and, waste, and
            sediments will be disposed of in accordance to environmental measures.
